 * JOKR: 2/3 usuarios la habían usado. La incluí especificamente porque tienen
   un modelo de operación distinto que resultó interesante para los usuarios:
   tiendas en distintas ubicaciones y un app organizado por categorías, en vez
   de pedir de tiendas específicas.

Algunos de los insights de las entrevistas:



También observé a los usuarios haciendo un pedido en las dos apps mencionadas.
Algo que me pareció interesante es que los tres usaron primero la función de 
búsqueda para encontrar productos con sus restricciones. Los tres usuarios
decidieron optar por productos que ya conocían como aptos para ellos o que
habían probado antes, a pesar de que los tres manifestaron interés en probar
snacks nuevos.

Las categorías en si también resultaron ser poco efectivas para encontrar
productos. En el caso de Rappi en específico sirvieron para encontrar tiendas de
comida saludable como Flora y Fauna, más no para diferenciar los productos con
restricciones. En el caso de JOKR, existía una categoría específicamente de
snacks con varias subcategorías, sin embargo ninguna de estas hacía referencia a
los ingredientes de los productos y la información de cada producto no incluía
ingredientes o composición. 

Aproveché para observar el journey de los usuarios al usar Rappi, y armé un
diagrama de costumer journey para visualizarlo mejor.

Claramente, el problema principal del journey del usuario consistía en no
encontrar información precisa de los alimentos y no poder consumir alimentos de
manera espontánea.Los usuarios se decepcionan con las posibilidades de filtro de
búsqueda en Rappi. Prefieren consumir algo que ya hayan consumido antes no solo
por una cuestión de seguridad, si no también por el elevado precio de los
alimentos que pueden consumir. Si compran algo que al final no pueden comer se
vuelve un gasto inecesario.

Una de las principales frustraciones del usuario, entonces, es sentir que no
tiene poder sobre los alimentos que consume. Se ve forzado a seguir consumiendo
las mismas cosas de manera monótona y no puede probar nada nuevo. Que el usuario
se sienta sin poder de desición es un pain point terrible que sin duda hace que
cualquier ecperiencia relacionada a la comida por delivery sea potencialmente
una mala experiencia.

A partir de estas observaciones, construí dos personas basadas en los dos tipos
de usuarios principales:

La estructura
Para definir las limitaciones del concepto se "snack" también realizé un
ejercicio de card sorting con los usuarios.

Interesantemente, hubo bastante controversia respecto a si un sandwich califica
como un snack o no. El concenso al final fue que si bien un sandwich podría ser
un snack, no sería el tipo de snack que los usuarios pedirian en un app
dediacada solo a snacks, si no que la pedirían de un restaurante.

En el segundo ejercicio, llegamos a las siguientes categorías: 

Frutos secos y galletas eran una categoría en sí. Algunos productos podían ser
salados o dulces. Además, los usuarios mencionaron que si bien no veían a las
bebidas como snakcks, si les gustaría poder pedir snacks y bebidas en un mismo
app.

A partir de la investigación, ordené delimité las principales funciones del app:

Para el MVP, las funciones fundamentales (a parte de las de delivery/e-commerce)
fueron los filtros por ingredientes restringidos, lista de ingredientes e
información nutricional claramente demarcada y visible en cada página de
producto.

El flujo de uso reflejana también estas seis secciones delimitadas, así como el
camino que seguiría el usuario para realizar el task principal.

 Una vez delimitada toda la estructura del app, realicé los wireframes y el
prototipo low fi del mvp:

MVPEl testeo con los usuarios demostró ser un alivio de los pain points
descubiertos en las entrevistas. Al tratarse por ahora solo del MVP, otras
funciones del app como una lista de favoritos o comentarios en los productos
podrían agregar más valor al producto final.

En el lado negativo, los usuarios recalcaron que el sistema de quitar/cambiar un
producto en la página del producto era algo confuso, y que preferirían tener dos
botones separados para cada función. 

La imagen
Por último, diseñé un estilo visual del app y sus principales componenetes.

Para el logo y los colores de la marca, escogí tonos verde oscuro con acentros
rosa vibrante. Uno de mis objetivos al diseñar la linea visual del aplicativo
fue hacerla claramente diferenciable de otras aplicaciones de comida. En los
ultimos años se ha visto un auge de aplicaciones de delivery, muchas de ellas
con estilos visuales similares. Quize apartarme de los amarillos, rojos y
anaranjados que suelen tener este tipo de apliciones. 

En el caso de los botones, hay dos variantes definidas: una redondeada y rosa
usada para acciones de interacción (ir a la página siguiente, aceptar un input)
y otra de bordes rectos y verde oscuro, usada para los botones de compra.

Para la tipografía, utilicé open sans para una legibilidad óptima, además de la
escala de texto usada en Material Design,

Los elementos más importantes en este diseño son sin duda las tarjetas y
etiquetas. Los productos son contenidos en tarjetas, así como la información
relevante sobre ellos. Las etiquetas cargan la información de los
alérgenos/restricciones. El reto fue hacer que estos dos elementos fueran al
mismo tiempo distintivos y coherentes.

Para unificar estos elementos, opté por usar shades de los mismos colores de
apoyo para las tarjetas y etiquetas. El color ayuda a separarlos del fondo, así
como la sombra.

Para las tarjetas de productos, el verdadero protagonista es la foto. Las cartas
de productos dejan casi todo su espacio para ser rellenado por fotos. En mi
opinión, es esencial que un app de comida le de el protagonismo a sus fotos de
producto. Así. el ususuario puede "escanear" más fácilmente una lista de
productos, por ejemplo, sin la necesidad de leer el nombre de cada producto.

Mockups finales¿Qué sigue ahora?

Este es un proyecto que me gustaría retomar en un tiempo. Con más entrevistas y
testeos, me gustaría optimizar la experiencia del usuario para que sea lo más
efectiva y buena posible.
posts.custom_excerpt: Aplicación de dellivery de snacks para personas con restricciones alimenticias.

posts.html:
2021

Personal Project

See the final website here

Check out the code I used to analyze this data.

The project

In order to learn data analysis in python and improve my data visualization skills, I decided to start a short project comparing the most popular songs of the years 2020 and 2010.

The process

I performed all the tasks in this project, from design and illustration to data analysis and data cleaning in python.

To build the database, I merged two Kaggle datasets, one with data from Spotify , containing general information about the songs: release date, rating as explicit, duration, etc; and the other with all the Billboard entries by date with rank. I used the Pandas library to do all the analysis and Plotly for the visualizations.

The data

As soon as I started examining the data, the differences between the two years became clear: not only were there more artists and more songs making it into the Billboard Hot 100 in 2020, in addition, the percentage of explicit songs had significantly increased.

When I dug deeper  something struck me about the list of songs that had reached number 1. The musical/genre was obvious, but also there were now fewer "repeat" artists. The most popular songs were no longer just Katy Perry or Bruno Mars songs, there was a bit more variety.

This realization, combined with the reduction in song lengths and more explicit songs in general seemed to suggest that in the last decade, musical change had been driven by music distribution channels. Streaming vs. radio, greater access to varied artists, less use of censored versions of explicit songs, internet trends that had put songs from several years earlier back on the chart...radio seemed to have lost ground as the trend-setting metronome.

So I decided to focus my analysis on these indicators of change: music genres, duration, number of artists, number of weeks in the rank per song, etc.

In order to analyze the changes in the most popular music genres in the chart, I decided to focus exclusively on the songs that had reached number one. Getting accurate genre data for all the song in the chart proved to be a bit too difficult to do, so I opted to limit my analysis.  From this list of number 1 hits, I manually logged the genres and sub-genres of each song from Wikipedia. I considered the following to be the main (or "parent") genres:

For each sub-genre, I considered two of these main genres as "parents". For example, in the case of dance-pop (a subgenre with influences from pop and electronic music, often house music), its parents were Pop and EDM. Each song had between one and three subgenres on Wikipedia, so I classified each of them into their respective genres/sub-genres.

To keep the analysis simple, I limited the parents to only two genres. I also included disco and funk in the R&B category and any type of electronic music in EDM one.

Other interesting observations included: number of weeks in the chart per song, artists per song, artists in both decades, etc. One interesting observation that I didn't get to include on the final website is the relationship between the date of first appearance on Billboard vs. the date of highest ranking. I didn't include it in this version of the analysis because I want to dig deeper into it. However, at a glance it is evident that in 2020 the songs reached their best position in much less time than in 2010.

The structure

After analyzing the data, I decided to present it in a simple web page, with SVG graphics and visualizations, for practicality.  The Plotly visualization library includes a function to export the graphics in svg, so I based on that to create the visualizations.

To organize my ideas on how to present the analysis, I made a Wireframe. I wanted the data to tell a story, to follow a logical line. I organized it that way.

The wireframe helped me realize something of utmost importance: it was necessary to adapt each graphic or data visualization graph to three different sizes (desktop, tablet and mobile) so that they could be appreciated well. Perhaps the biggest disadvantage of doing this project with SVG and not with a library like D3 is that SVG is not responsive by itself. As soon as I exported the graphics as html from Plotly I also realized that if I wanted to use them as HTML they would require a lot of customization and code to make them look the way I wanted. So in the end I opted to adapt the graphs myself to three different sizes.

I chose three specific dimensions that best suited the different types of visualizations.

I already had the analysis, I already had the plots/graphs adapted. I wanted to create a one-page site that would host this project and its future.

For the most "tangible" part of the project, the web, I started looking for references. I've always liked the aesthetics of virtual instruments or VST, they have a charm that is old-fashioned and avant-garde at the same time. Like a nineties idea of futurism.

Initially, I wanted to create something with a similar feel. The underlying theme of the analysis - how the shift towards streaming is trending in the structure and shape of popular music today - seemed to resonate quite well with this style.

However, the first concepts I made with this idea in mind did not convince me.

Perhaps what made this aesthetic fit so well with VSTS is that the very concept of a virtual instrument is quite retro-futuristic. And the fact is also that the overloaded interfaces full of knobs and audio waveform that are so common in virtual instruments exist because the very functionality of the virtual instrument warrants it. It looks cluttered, yes, but in the end every element of that interface serves an important function.

I didn't want to abandon the concept entirely, but I wanted to modify it. I still wanted the website to have a dark interface, with contrasting vibrant colors. Without going too far from the music sphere, Spotify itself had this visual identity that caught my attention.

I decided to bite the bullet and try modifying what I had already done. Maybe a little less cluttered, maybe a lesser amount of different shades of grey. I already had in mind the colors to I'd use to differentiate 2010 and 2020, so I started from them to generate more components.

Cards were the main building block for this UI. Apart from graphics and visualizations, all the important information was going to be contained within cards. I didn't want to use a lot of text on the website (that's why I expand on it here), so the cards were my raw material to build the site.

I decided to clean them of all unnecessary elements, lines, shadows, etc, and use mainly text and color. I differentiated the cards with colors by year to make the reading of the data easier.

By focusing on cleaning up the UI elements, I managed to come up with a concept that I liked. From the wirefrme, I rebuilt each component in its cleanest version.

I wanted there to be a lot of contrast. Between the background and the text, the data and the background, the cards of one year versus another. The typographic scale also had to be contrasting. It's a comparison, an analysis that puts two moments in time one versus the other, so I decided to emphasize that contrast.

For the typographic scale I used a slightly modified version of 1.4 (rounded down instead of up) to ensure high contrast between the titles and the body. To further emphasize this contrast, I set the titles in black or bold.

One of the most complicated sections to design was the music genres.part. In the wireframe I had planned to have information from both years side by side and separate them by borders. I wanted the user to be able to compare the two states in one place, to see how the distribution of each genre had moved.

In my mission to clean up the whole UI, I thought I'd get rid of that concept and put each graphic/card one after the other, interspersing years. But it wasn't working. It didn't have the same punch. Obviously this layout was only possible on pc, tablet or mobile would be to small for it In the end, I kept the idea of having them together but I added badges to differentiate the year and used blurred color shadows instead of solid borders.

The most difficult task was actually adapting the visualizations to the graphic style of the site. I wanted to be as accurate as possible with the data, but there were visualizations that were simply not pleasant to read (like the one below, right). I had to decide when to cut non-essential information and what to keep in each plot.

Finally, I made some decorative illustrations to break down the introduction and make it easier to read. I also made an illustration for the header

I developed the site in HTML and CSS using a modified version of Bootstrap with SASS. The final site is live at this link (through Netlify)

to varied artists, less use of censored versions of explicit songs, internet
trends that had put songs from several years earlier back on the chart...radio
seemed to have lost ground as the trend-setting metronome.

Porcentaje de canciones explicitas por cada año. Gráfico extraido directamente
de Plotly

So I decided to focus my analysis on these indicators of change: music genres,
duration, number of artists, number of weeks in the rank per song, etc.

Artistas con el número 1 en más semanas, 2010 vs 2020In order to analyze the
changes in the most popular music genres in the chart, I decided to focus
exclusively on the songs that had reached number one. Getting accurate genre
data for all the song in the chart proved to be a bit too difficult to do, so I
opted to limit my analysis.  From this list of number 1 hits, I manually logged
the genres and sub-genres of each song from Wikipedia. I considered the
following to be the main (or "parent") genres:

For each sub-genre, I considered two of these main genres as "parents". For
example, in the case of dance-pop (a subgenre with influences from pop and
electronic music, often house music), its parents were Pop and EDM. Each song
had between one and three subgenres on Wikipedia, so I classified each of them
into their respective genres/sub-genres.

To keep the analysis simple, I limited the parents to only two genres. I also
included disco and funk in the R&B category and any type of electronic music in
EDM one.

Lista de canciones con géneros/subgéneros, 2010Lista de canciones con
géneros/subgéneros, 2020Other interesting observations included: number of weeks
in the chart per song, artists per song, artists in both decades, etc. One
interesting observation that I didn't get to include on the final website is the
relationship between the date of first appearance on Billboard vs. the date of
highest ranking. I didn't include it in this version of the analysis because I
want to dig deeper into it. However, at a glance it is evident that in 2020 the
songs reached their best position in much less time than in 2010.

The structure
After analyzing the data, I decided to present it in a simple web page, with SVG
graphics and visualizations, for practicality.  The Plotly visualization library
includes a function to export the graphics in svg, so I based on that to create
the visualizations.

To organize my ideas on how to present the analysis, I made a Wireframe. I
wanted the data to tell a story, to follow a logical line. I organized it that
way.

Wireframe del sitioThe wireframe helped me realize something of utmost
importance: it was necessary to adapt each graphic or data visualization graph
to three different sizes (desktop, tablet and mobile) so that they could be
appreciated well. Perhaps the biggest disadvantage of doing this project with
SVG and not with a library like D3 is that SVG is not responsive by itself. As
soon as I exported the graphics as html from Plotly I also realized that if I
wanted to use them as HTML they would require a lot of customization and code to
make them look the way I wanted. So in the end I opted to adapt the graphs
myself to three different sizes.

I chose three specific dimensions that best suited the different types of
visualizations.

Dos gráficos en tres tamaños.I already had the analysis, I already had the
plots/graphs adapted. I wanted to create a one-page site that would host this
project and its future.

For the most "tangible" part of the project, the web, I started looking for
references. I've always liked the aesthetics of virtual instruments or VST, they
have a charm that is old-fashioned and avant-garde at the same time. Like a
nineties idea of futurism.

Ui - Serum VSTInitially, I wanted to create something with a similar feel. The
underlying theme of the analysis - how the shift towards streaming is trending
in the structure and shape of popular music today - seemed to resonate quite
well with this style.

However, the first concepts I made with this idea in mind did not convince me.

hmmmPerhaps what made this aesthetic fit so well with VSTS is that the very
concept of a virtual instrument is quite retro-futuristic. And the fact is also
that the overloaded interfaces full of knobs and audio waveform that are so
common in virtual instruments exist because the very functionality of the
virtual instrument warrants it. It looks cluttered, yes, but in the end every
element of that interface serves an important function.

I didn't want to abandon the concept entirely, but I wanted to modify it. I
still wanted the website to have a dark interface, with contrasting vibrant
colors. Without going too far from the music sphere, Spotify itself had this
visual identity that caught my attention.

UI de spotify, adjacente al cocepto que originalmente tenía para el sitio.I
decided to bite the bullet and try modifying what I had already done. Maybe a
little less cluttered, maybe a lesser amount of different shades of grey. I
already had in mind the colors to I'd use to differentiate 2010 and 2020, so I
started from them to generate more components.

colores para cada añoCards were the main building block for this UI. Apart from
graphics and visualizations, all the important information was going to be
contained within cards. I didn't want to use a lot of text on the website
(that's why I expand on it here), so the cards were my raw material to build the
site.

I decided to clean them of all unnecessary elements, lines, shadows, etc, and
use mainly text and color. I differentiated the cards with colors by year to
make the reading of the data easier.

By focusing on cleaning up the UI elements, I managed to come up with a concept
that I liked. From the wirefrme, I rebuilt each component in its cleanest
version.

las tarjetas de géneros, antes y despuésI wanted there to be a lot of contrast.
Between the background and the text, the data and the background, the cards of
one year versus another. The typographic scale also had to be contrasting. It's
a comparison, an analysis that puts two moments in time one versus the other, so
I decided to emphasize that contrast.

For the typographic scale I used a slightly modified version of 1.4 (rounded
down instead of up) to ensure high contrast between the titles and the body. To
further emphasize this contrast, I set the titles in black or bold.



One of the most complicated sections to design was the music genres.part. In the
wireframe I had planned to have information from both years side by side and
separate them by borders. I wanted the user to be able to compare the two states
in one place, to see how the distribution of each genre had moved.

In my mission to clean up the whole UI, I thought I'd get rid of that concept
and put each graphic/card one after the other, interspersing years. But it
wasn't working. It didn't have the same punch. Obviously this layout was only
possible on pc, tablet or mobile would be to small for it In the end, I kept the
idea of having them together but I added badges to differentiate the year and
used blurred color shadows instead of solid borders.

wireframe vs diseño finalThe most difficult task was actually adapting the
visualizations to the graphic style of the site. I wanted to be as accurate as
possible with the data, but there were visualizations that were simply not
pleasant to read (like the one below, right). I had to decide when to cut
non-essential information and what to keep in each plot.

plots directamente exportados vs versión finalFinally, I made some decorative
illustrations to break down the introduction and make it easier to read. I also
made an illustration for the header

Ilustraciones para la webI developed the site in HTML and CSS using a modified
version of Bootstrap with SASS. The final site is live at this link (through
Netlify)

posts.html:
2021

Personal Project

See the low fi prototype here

The project

I have celiac disease. That means I can't eat wheat, barley and rye. In principle that sounds simple, but in practice it's quite complicated: not all products or restaurants declare all the ingredients they use and gluten can be everywhere, even in things that seem as innocuous as tea. Not to mention the complexity of cross-contamination and all the restrictions that entails.

I rarely eat out anymore and I can't order a lot of things by delivery because I can't physically be in the store to read the labels. It's almost impossible for me to try something new because I can't tell if it has gluten or not.

Snackoo came about as an idea for a Rappi with an ingredient list. The idea was to be able to order snacks at any time without having to do the whole process of research, trial and error to find out if you can eat something. It sounds like an obvious solution, but I needed the insights of other people with dietary restrictions.

Process

The users

Among my acquaintances, I recruited three people with dietary restrictions: two with medical restrictions and one vegan person.

I focused the questions on understanding the user experience when ordering snacks through other delivery apps, specifically Rappi and JOKR. I chose these two apps specifically for two reasons.

  • Rappi: In the experience of the users interviewed, it is the most used app for ordering snacks.
  • JOKR: 2/3 users had used it. I included it specifically because they have a different operating model that was interesting for users: stores in different locations and an app organized by categories, instead of asking for specific stores.

Some of the insights from the interviews:

I also observed users placing an order on the two apps mentioned above. One thing I found interesting is that all three used the search function first to find any products that cater to their restrictions. All three users decided to go for products they already knew were suitable for them or that they had tried before, even though all three expressed interest in trying new snacks.

The categories themselves also proved to be ineffective for finding products. In the case of Rappi specifically, they were useful for finding health food stores such as Flora and Fauna, but not for differentiating products with restrictions. In the case of JOKR, there was a category specifically for snacks with several subcategories, however none of these made reference to the ingredients of the products and the information for each product did not include ingredients or composition.

I took the opportunity to observe the user journey when using Rappi, and put together a costumer journey diagram to better visualize it.

Clearly, the biggest pain point in the user journey was not finding accurate food information and not being able to consume food spontaneously.  Users are disappointed with the search filter possibilities on Rappi. They prefer to consume something they have already consumed before not only because of a safety issue, but also because of the high price of the food they can consume. If they buy something they can't eat in the end, it becomes an unnecessary expense.

One of the main frustrations of the user, then, is feeling that they have no power over the food they eat. They are forced to continue consuming the same things in a monotonous way and can't try anything new. That the user feels disempowered is a terrible pain point that undoubtedly makes any experience related to food delivery a potentially bad experience.

From these observations, I constructed two personas based on the two main types of users:

The structure

To define the limitations of the "snack" concept, I also conducted a card sorting exercise with the users.

Interestingly, there was quite a bit of controversy as to whether a sandwich qualifies as a snack or not. The consensus in the end was that while a sandwich might be a snack, it would not be the type of snack that users would order from a snack-only app, but would order from a restaurant.

In the second exercise, we arrive at the following categories:

Nuts and biscuits were a category in itself. Some products could be salty or sweet. In addition, users mentioned that while they didn't see drinks as snacks, they would like to be able to order snacks and drinks in the same app.

From this research, I sorted out the main functions of the app:

For the MVP, the key features (apart from delivery/e-commerce) were the restricted ingredient filters, ingredient list and nutritional information clearly demarcated and visible on each product page.

The user flow also reflects these six delimited sections, as well as the path the user would follow to perform the main task.

Once the whole structure of the app was defined, I made the wireframes and the low fi prototype of the mvp:

User testing proved the presented solution to be a relief from the pain points discovered in the interviews. As this is only the MVP for now, other features of the app such as a list of favorites or comments on products could add more value to the final product.

On the negative side, users stressed that the system for removing/changing a product on the product page was somewhat confusing, and that they would prefer to have two separate buttons for each function.

Visual identity

Finally, I designed a visual style for the app and its main components.

For the logo and brand colors, I chose dark green tones with vibrant pink accents. One of my goals when designing the visual style of the app was to make it clearly differentiable from other food apps. The last few years have seen a boom in delivery apps, many of them with similar visual styles. I wanted to move away from the yellows, reds and oranges that this kind of apps usually have.

In the case of buttons, there are two defined variants: one rounded and pink used for interaction actions (go to the next page, accept an input) and another one with straight edges and dark green, used for purchase buttons. As the users suggested, the second button needs another run of iteration to match the user's expectations.

For typography, I used open sans for optimal readability, in addition to the text scale used in Material Design,

The most important elements in this design are undoubtedly the cards and tags. The products are contained within cards, as well as relevant information about them. The tags carry the allergen information/restrictions. The challenge was to make these two elements both distinctive and coherent.

To unify these elements, I opted to use shades of the same supporting colors for the cards and tags. The color helps to separate them from the background, as well as a subtle box shadow.

For product cards, the real protagonist is the photo. Product cards leave almost all their space to be filled by photos. In my opinion, it is essential for a food app to give prominence to its product photos. This way, the user can more easily "scan" a list of products, for example, without the need to read the name of each product.

What's next?

This is a project I'd like to take up again in a while. With more interviews and testing, I would like to optimize the user experience to make it as effective and good as possible.

used for interaction actions (go to the next page, accept an input) and another
one with straight edges and dark green, used for purchase buttons. As the users
suggested, the second button needs another run of iteration to match the user's
expectations.

For typography, I used open sans for optimal readability, in addition to the
text scale used in Material Design,

The most important elements in this design are undoubtedly the cards and tags.
The products are contained within cards, as well as relevant information about
them. The tags carry the allergen information/restrictions. The challenge was to
make these two elements both distinctive and coherent.

To unify these elements, I opted to use shades of the same supporting colors for
the cards and tags. The color helps to separate them from the background, as
well as a subtle box shadow.

For product cards, the real protagonist is the photo. Product cards leave almost
all their space to be filled by photos. In my opinion, it is essential for a
food app to give prominence to its product photos. This way, the user can more
easily "scan" a list of products, for example, without the need to read the name
of each product.

Final mockupsWhat's next?

This is a project I'd like to take up again in a while. With more interviews and
testing, I would like to optimize the user experience to make it as effective
and good as possible.
